channel.title: Cut the crap
channel.description:
This isn't a site suggestion as it is more of a "reminder" to the people who bitch and whine about the site's staff and why it sucks. More particularly, the people who act like total faggots, and then whine about elitism being the cause of it. This site is what you make it, so if you want it to be good, contribute. This can be constructive criticism as long as it is [b]constructive[/b] (I bolded constructive, because "l0o0o0ol DiS SuCkS Pp LiEk Ur mOM" is not), and obviously, original content. This of course doesn't mean suck up to the noobs, you can of course criticize their work, as long as you provide a reason for it.* You see a flame? Ignore it. Someone flaming you? Take it to PM or ignore them completely, and let them get in trouble instead of you both. The staff aren't the problem, it's the fact that they have to deal with people who act like idiots and spam/flame.
From now on, you won't see any of that bullshit from me, and I hope everyone does the same.
*P.S. Before you ask, I do most certainly believe that Tico's warnings in the GFX board were unjust. Yes the guy might be new and all, but was still acting like an arrogant prick after the people told him what to do [next or instead] and not to brag about his beginner-level work. This does not mean that I dislike Tico as GM, however I do believe he went a tad overboard with that.
Also, this is another message this topic is trying to convey: [quote="Thug-life"]Why do you somehow think we have to be perfect in everything we do? We are allowed to make mistakes, you know?[/quote]

Oh, wait, moparscape…[/quote]

Terrible analogy, for mscp is crap because crap is contributed there.

Read full topic

item.title: Cut the crap
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Greeny, post:40, topic:238329”][quote author=belbn link=topic=314602.msg2503469#msg2503469 date=1224802671]
When a thread—or in some cases an entire forum—becomes unstable the result is usually uncontrolled spam in the form of one-line complaints, image macros or rude behavior. When the discussion becomes heated and sides do nothing more than complain and not accept each other’s differences in point of view, the discussion degenerates into what is called a flame war. To flame someone means to go off-topic and attack the person rather than their opinion. Likely candidates for flame wars are usually religion, political or otherwise sensitive topics. Topics which degenerate are usually locked but when the problem is considered contagious they are deleted.

When a topic that has degenerated into a flame war is considered akin to that of the forum (be it a section or the entire board) spam and flames have a chance of spreading outside the topic and causing trouble, usually in the form of vandalism. Some forums (commonly game forums) have suffer from forum wide flame wars almost immediately after their conception, because of a pre-existing flame war element in the online community.

A flame war isn’t always associated or considered a breach of rules if troll or spam like behavior doesn’t accompany the usual rude replies or unsocial behavior. Since they can easily be passed as simply a “heated discussion” it is not uncommon for moderators to cast a blind eye upon them in the hope both parties exhaust each other in the one thread instead of spreading vandalism into others.
[/quote]

You just produced three paragraphs explaining words everyone already understands. Congratulations.

Having said that, how much of all that wasn’t copied from here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_forums[/quote]

Wow, talk about plagiarism…

Read full topic

*P.S. Before you ask, I do most certainly believe that Tico’s warnings in the GFX board were unjust. Yes the guy might be new

He’s not new to warning power, he’s had it over at mscp for a long time.

I honestly love Tico but I believe the power is getting a tad bit to his head.

As to the other thoughts: it’s a forum. more so the internet. Your not cool when you think you are by spamming/flaming etc.

Why act as if you’re above it when you were a cunt, and still are a cunt?

Done with your temper tantrum?[/quote]Yes. Sorry thug-life, didn’t mean for the personal attack.

I was just pissed at someone on MSN and took it out on you. You do a fine job.

item.title: Cut the crap
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

[quote=“belbn, post:36, topic:238329”]When a thread—or in some cases an entire forum—becomes unstable the result is usually uncontrolled spam in the form of one-line complaints, image macros or rude behavior. When the discussion becomes heated and sides do nothing more than complain and not accept each other’s differences in point of view, the discussion degenerates into what is called a flame war. To flame someone means to go off-topic and attack the person rather than their opinion. Likely candidates for flame wars are usually religion, political or otherwise sensitive topics. Topics which degenerate are usually locked but when the problem is considered contagious they are deleted.

When a topic that has degenerated into a flame war is considered akin to that of the forum (be it a section or the entire board) spam and flames have a chance of spreading outside the topic and causing trouble, usually in the form of vandalism. Some forums (commonly game forums) have suffer from forum wide flame wars almost immediately after their conception, because of a pre-existing flame war element in the online community.

A flame war isn’t always associated or considered a breach of rules if troll or spam like behavior doesn’t accompany the usual rude replies or unsocial behavior. Since they can easily be passed as simply a “heated discussion” it is not uncommon for moderators to cast a blind eye upon them in the hope both parties exhaust each other in the one thread instead of spreading vandalism into others.[/quote]

You just produced three paragraphs explaining words everyone already understands. Congratulations.

Having said that, how much of all that wasn’t copied from here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_forums

item.title: Cut the crap
item.dc:creator: @ilyaostr9 io9
item.description:
@ilyaostr9 wrote:

ThAtOn36Uy requested that I post this here:

[quote=“ThAtOn36Uy on MSN”]ThAtOn36Uy says (2:54 AM):
Are you there? Well when you get this message I want to tell you that I support your topic.
ThAtOn36Uy says (2:55 AM):
I’ve come to a decision to present myself with a greater air of responsibility, and respect for others.
ThAtOn36Uy says (2:56 AM):
If you wouldn’t mind being my voice in your topic, just quote what I tell you what I want said, and maybe you’ll get some more support then.
ThAtOn36Uy says (2:57 AM):
I think you’re very right in what you said. I need to act much more mature, instead of just flaming people all the time, there’s no reason I can’t be constructive, and help support this community in my own way.[/quote]

Read full topic

item.title: Cut the crap
item.dc:creator: @belbn belbn
item.description:
@belbn wrote:

When a thread—or in some cases an entire forum—becomes unstable the result is usually uncontrolled spam in the form of one-line complaints, image macros or rude behavior. When the discussion becomes heated and sides do nothing more than complain and not accept each other’s differences in point of view, the discussion degenerates into what is called a flame war. To flame someone means to go off-topic and attack the person rather than their opinion. Likely candidates for flame wars are usually religion, political or otherwise sensitive topics. Topics which degenerate are usually locked but when the problem is considered contagious they are deleted.

When a topic that has degenerated into a flame war is considered akin to that of the forum (be it a section or the entire board) spam and flames have a chance of spreading outside the topic and causing trouble, usually in the form of vandalism. Some forums (commonly game forums) have suffer from forum wide flame wars almost immediately after their conception, because of a pre-existing flame war element in the online community.

A flame war isn’t always associated or considered a breach of rules if troll or spam like behavior doesn’t accompany the usual rude replies or unsocial behavior. Since they can easily be passed as simply a “heated discussion” it is not uncommon for moderators to cast a blind eye upon them in the hope both parties exhaust each other in the one thread instead of spreading vandalism into others.

Read full topic
